document.docAuthor: Verdone, Chris J. & Kondratieff, Boris C.
document.masterDocTitle: A New Species Of Isoperla Banks (Plecoptera: Perlodidae) From The Southern Appalachians, With Notes On The I. Montana Group

caption.paragraph:
Figs. 23–25.
Isoperla smithi
, paratype, 3 mi. NE Mathias, 38°55’N, 78°49’W, Hardy Co., West Virginia. 23. Ovum, 300X. 24. Ovum collar, 1,000X. 25. Ovum follicle cell impressions and micropyles, 1,000X.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Canada – NS, ON, PQ. U.S.A. – CT, DE, IN, KY, ME, MN, NC, NH, NJ, NY, OH, PA, VA, WV ( Szczytko & Kondratieff 2015 ).

Biological notes.
Isoperla montana
is the most widespread species of the
I. montana
Group occurring from New Brunswick , Canada to North Carolina and west to Indiana ( Szczytko & Kondratieff 2015 ). The majority of Virginia records are from the Ridge and Valley Physiographic Province with few records east of this province, particularly in the southern part of the state. Szczytko and Kondratieff (2015) reported
I. montana
from North Carolina based on two females collected by the authors (CJV, BCK). As noted above, species determination of isolated females is difficult, especially in the southern Appalachians where the ranges of
I. montana
and
I. kirchneri
overlap, as such this record should be regarded as tentative. In addition to the material listed above, we also examined specimens of
I. montana
reported by Grubbs (2016) from Alabama. These specimens appear to represent an undescribed taxon based on details of the aedeagus and ovum, but more specimens with the aedeagus everted and mature ova are needed for confirmation.
